scenarioDescription:
The HD 114783 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 114783 is a star with 0.85 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.84 times its radius. It is located 68.70 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 7 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

HD 114783 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 114783 system


HD 114783 b

HD 114783 b was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2002-03, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 1.16 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 114783 b is 349.800 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 114783 b is 13.700 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 114783 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


HD 114783 c

HD 114783 c was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2016-04, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 4.97 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 114783 c is 194.298 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 114783 c is 14.100 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 114783 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system HD 114783, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory.
name: HD 114783 - System With 2 Exoplanets
